justification: “The 19-item Impulsivity and Sensation Seeking Scale (ImpSS; Zuckerman, 1999) measured impulsivity and sensation-seeking with true-or-false items.”
The same sentence notes that the ImpSS “measured impulsivity and sensation-seeking with true-or-false items.”

measured_by: Single-item ideology rating (-3 = mostly liberal to 3 = mostly conservative)
justification: “The first was a single item (-3 = mostly liberal to 3 = mostly conservative)” used to assess participants’ political orientation.
“The second was the Social and Economic Conservatism Scale (SECS; Everett, 2013)… items … measured people’s feelings about social … conservative issues.”
The SECS “separately measured people’s feelings about social (e.g., ‘traditional values’) and economic (e.g., ‘fiscal responsibility’) conservative issues.”
“The 20-item International Personality Item Pool (Mini-IPIP… ) measured the Big-Five personality traits: agreeableness … ”.
The same Mini-IPIP description lists “conscientiousness (e.g., ‘I like order’)” among the traits assessed.
Mini-IPIP also measured “openness (e.g., ‘I have a vivid imagination’).”
Mini-IPIP included “extraversion (e.g., ‘I am the life of the party’).”
“Study 3 used the 44-item Big Five Inventory (BFI-44; John & Srivastava, 1999) rather than the Mini-IPIP … to measure Big-Five personality traits.”

measured_by: Behavior likelihood inventory based on Ready.gov / NOAA items
justification: “To measure hurricane-related behavior likelihood, participants completed a behavior inventory comprised of items from Ready.gov … such as ‘cover windows’ or ‘learn evacuation routes’.”
“To measure perceived threat, participants used a 15-item checklist to indicate the safety concerns they had about hurricanes … we summed the number of checks.”

measured_by: Threat-word rating scale (average of five threat words)
justification: Participants “indicated the extent to which a list of 10 words … described hurricanes … We took the average rating of the five threat words … to obtain a composite threat perception score.”

measured_by: Single-item likelihood of being in the path of a hurricane (0–100 scale)
justification: “Using a scale from 0 (not likely) to 100 (highly likely), participants rated their perceived likelihood of being in the path of a hurricane.”
